"1049662033", "name": "Paul Steinberg"}]}, "created_time": "2014-03-03T15:54:36+0000", "message": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute is partnering with the Central Texas Regional Mobility Authority (CTRMA) and Carma Austin, a real-time ridesharing vendor, to test a carpool pilot program in Austin. The program uses a mobile app to match riders to carpools. Riders pay $0.20 per mile of travel, and drivers receive $0.17 per rider (up to a maximum of $0.51 for all riders). Drivers also have the option of accepting free rides.\n\nAdditionally, there are toll discounts for travel on the 183A Toll Road and US 290 (the Manor Expressway). Drivers of two-person carpools get 50% off their tolls and those with three or more passengers ride toll-free! Try carpooling today! Go to: https://www.car.ma/austin.", "caption": "www.car.ma", "type": "link", "id": "311158400744_10203298762298232", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "Thanks to our pilot program with the Central Texas Regional Mobility Authority, you can get toll reimbursements when you carpool along 183A and Manor Expressway with the Carma app! 2-person carpools get 50% of the toll back, and 3+ person carpools get the full toll amount reimbursed."}

TTI\u2019s role is multi-faceted and includes inspecting the adaptive equipment prescribed for individuals. Since 1999, the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) has worked with the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) (AASHTO) and the American Traffic Safety Services Association to coordinate and sponsor the event. Very pleased to see A&M producing this type of transportation research.", "id": "559135827432716_6620285", "user_likes": false}]}, "message": "The 2012 Urban Mobility Report is out today from Texas A&M Transportation Institute!  The Planning Time Index (PTI), a measure of travel reliability, illustrates the amount of extra time needed to arrive on time for higher priority events, such as an airline departure, just-in-time shipments, medical appointments or especially important social commitments. If the PTI for a particular trip is 3.00, a traveler would allow 60 minutes for a trip that typically takes 20 minutes when few cars are on the road. Allowing for a PTI of 3.00 would ensure on-time arrival 19 out of 20 times.  How much time to you allow for important trips?", "caption": "tti.tamu.edu", "type": "link", "id": "311158400744_559135827432716", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "As traffic congestion continues to worsen, the time required for a given trip becomes more unpredictable, and researchers now have a way to measure that degree of unreliability, introduced for the ..."}

{"picture": "https://fbexternal-a.akamaihd.net/safe_image.php?d=AQD40jup4X1M7-Kd&w=154&h=154&url=http%3A%2F%2Ftti.tamu.edu%2Fwp%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2012%2F11%2FAllin-Grandchildren.jpg", "from": {"category": "University", "name": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute", "category_list": [{"id": "108051929285833", "name": "College & University"}], "id": "311158400744"}, "name": "First Port of Houston General Manager Honored", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif", "message_tags": {"59": [{"length": 15, "offset": 59, "type": "page", "id": "164949723660", "name": "Port of Houston"}]}, "privacy": {"value": ""}, "actions": [{"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/128862080603787", "name": "Comment"}, {"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/128862080603787", "name": "Like"}], "updated_time": "2012-11-26T17:12:10+0000", "to": {"data": [{"category": "Local business", "name": "Port of Houston", "category_list": [{"id": "187133811318958", "name": "Business Services"}], "id": "164949723660"}]}, "application": {"name": "Share_bookmarklet", "id": "5085647995"}, "link": "http://tti.tamu.edu/2012/11/26/first-port-of-houston-general-manager-honored/", "created_time": "2012-11-26T17:12:10+0000", "message": "Benjamin Casey Allin III, the first general manager of the Port of Houston Authority, was inducted into the Texas Transportation Hall of Honor Sept. 12. All six of his grandchildren were present to accept the honor on his behalf at a luncheon in Houston co-sponsored by TTI and the Houston East End Chamber of Commerce.\n \nDuring his 12 years as general manager (1919\u20131931), Houston\u2019s Port Authority transformed into the most efficient port in the country. Exports grew by 1,000 percent, and the port itself grew to become the sixth largest in the nation.\n\nDuring Allin\u2019s tenure, the Port Authority was the first to ship cotton directly to Europe from the United States, helping make Houston the leader in cotton trade. He also helped reform port governance and implement $4 million in bond issue-approved port improvements. He later worked at other ports around the world until his death in 1960.\n\nToday, the Port of Houston is 1st ranked US port in foreign tonnage and 2nd ranked US port in total tonnage. Getting as close to the real thing as possible \u2014 in a controlled environment where results can be reproduced \u2014 is an important part of the Texas A&M Transportation Institute's Hydraulics, Sedimentation and Erosion Control Laboratory (HSECL) \u2014 a facility that will soon be expanding. The HSECL currently tests erosion-control products on two soil beds at a time. An upcoming expansion will add three test beds in a second indoor rainfall simulator building.  \u201cThe new test beds will conform to ASTM International\u2019s criteria for testing. This will lend even more credibility to our data and ensure that we have good options for products that perform as stated, to stop erosion and provide good future performance. Numerous states use our data to make decisions as well.\u201d  Dennis Markwardt, TxDOT director of vegetation management", "caption": "tti.tamu.edu", "type": "link", "id": "311158400744_131738106974024", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "TTI's mission is to solve transportation problems through research, to transfer technology, and to develop diverse human resources to meet the transportation challenges of tomorrow.\u00bb Learn more"}

The webinar is designed for public and private sector practicing engineers and will serve as an educational short course on the topic of asphalt modeling. \n\nThis webinar, organized by the TRB Standing Committee on Characteristics of Asphalt Paving Mixtures to Meet Structural Requirements (AFK50), is the first part of a two part series. The second webinar, which will take place on December 11, 2012, will focus on applications of asphalt modeling to understand various asphalt distresses and design materials to prevent them.  \n\nWebinar Presenters:\n\n    Eshan Dave, University of Minnesota Duluth\n    Amit Bhasin, University of Texas at Austin\n\nParticipants must register in advance of the webinar, and there is a fee for non-TRB Sponsor employees. {"application": {"name": "Share_bookmarklet", "id": "5085647995"}, "from": {"category": "University", "name": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute", "category_list": [{"id": "108051929285833", "name": "College & University"}], "id": "311158400744"}, "name": "Where the light is BETTER | Roads And Bridges", "privacy": {"value": ""}, "actions": [{"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/336587423076910", "name": "Comment"}, {"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/336587423076910", "name": "Like"}], "updated_time": "2012-06-08T18:07:51+0000", "caption": "www.roadsbridges.com", "link": "http://www.roadsbridges.com/where-light-better", "created_time": "2012-06-08T18:07:51+0000", "message": "#WorkZoneSafety: Most roadwork today involves reconstruction, rehabilitation and maintenance occurring near lanes of traffic on existing roadways. More and more agencies are doing roadwork on high-volume facilities at night to reduce traffic delays and complaints by the public that would typically be caused by doing the work during the day. In addition to several obvious advantages of nighttime work, such as fewer traffic delays and cooler temperatures for equipment and materials, there also are certain disadvantages.\n \nNight work comprises many complex issues and a variety of challenges, which include lighting conditions, safety, quality, manpower availability and administrative considerations. {"picture": "https://fbcdn-photos-d-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-frc3/t1.0-0/318184_10150955335401749_778238531_s.jpg", "story": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute shared American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)'s photo.", "from": {"category": "University", "name": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute", "category_list": [{"id": "108051929285833", "name": "College & University"}], "id": "311158400744"}, "name": "HootSuite Photos", "privacy": {"value": ""}, "actions": [{"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/311450422272472", "name": "Comment"}, {"link": "https://www.facebook.com/311158400744/posts/311450422272472", "name": "Like"}], "properties": [{"text": "American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)", "href": "https://www.facebook.com/AASHTOspeaks?ref=stream", "name": "By"}], "caption": "Today in Transportation History: June 4, 1896\n\nAt about four o\u2019clock in the morning and after two years of experimentation, automotive pioneer Henry Ford unveiled his recently completed \u201cFord Quadricycle\u201d and took it out for a test drive in Detroit, Michigan.  That vehicle, which was his first automobile, had a light metal frame supported by four bicycle wheels.  One likely reason why Ford named this vehicle a \u201cQuadricycle,\u201d as a matter of fact, was because of those four wheels.  The vehicle was propelled forward by an ethanol-powered, two-cylinder, four-horsepower engine and the fuel tank could be found under the seat.  In addition, this 500-pound automobile also had a doorbell button for a horn, and a transmission with only two gears \u2013 first for 10 miles per hour and second for 20 miles per hour.  There was no reverse gear, and the Ford Quadricycle also lacked brakes.  After putting the finishing touches on this new \u201chorseless carriage\u201d in the small workshop behind his home on Bagley Street, the 32-year-old Ford \u2013 with help from his chief assistant James Bishop -- tried to wheel the vehicle outside.  The vehicle, however, was too wide to make it out through that door.  Ford then took an axe and managed to make a large enough opening through a wall to roll out his Quadricycle.  Then, with Bishop bicycling ahead to warn carriages and pedestrians to stay out of the way, Ford drove the vehicle along Detroit\u2019s Grand River Avenue and circled three major thoroughfares.  The Quadricycle experienced one temporary breakdown due to a faulty spring, but otherwise the test drive proved to be a big success.  Ford went on to establish the Henry Ford Company, and then the Ford Motor Company, and the rest is transportation history.   That original Ford Quadricycle can be seen today at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan.", "application": {"name": "Photos", "id": "2305272732"}, "link": "https://www.facebook.com/AASHTOspeaks/photos/a.10150947963811749.406057.35722831748/10150955335401749/?type=1", "object_id": "10150955335401749", "story_tags": {"0": [{"length": 34, "offset": 0, "type": "page", "id": "311158400744", "name": "Texas A&M Transportation Institute"}], "42": [{"length": 75, "offset": 42, "type": "page", "id": "35722831748", "name": "American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)"}]}, "created_time": "2012-06-05T14:42:18+0000", "message": "Transportation history made today, June 4, 1896.", "updated_time": "2012-06-05T14:42:18+0000", "type": "photo", "id": "311158400744_311450422272472", "status_type": "shared_story", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif"}

A new tool kit for designing and constructing bridges brings home the benefits of accelerated bridge construction techniques so local contractors can use typical equipment to build bridges quickly and efficiently. Developed through the second Strategic Highway Research Program, a division of the Transportation Research Board, the tool kit was demonstrated in construction of a bridge over the Keg Creek near Council Bluffs, Iowa. The design reduced the road closure to only two weeks from a more typical 6 months. Time lapse photos at the end of the video show the construction."}

A few tips to help you reach your destination safely...\n\n\u2022  Turn on your headlights, its Kansas law. If your windshield wipers are on continuously, your headlights should also be on. This will help other motorists see you. \n\n\u2022  Turn off your cruise control so if you lose traction, your tires don\u2019t continue to spin. \n\n\u2022  Slow down and increase following distance between your vehicle and the vehicle traveling in front of you.", "type": "photo", "id": "311158400744_155491404569491", "status_type": "shared_story", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif"}

From speed limits to where the roadway curves, traffic signs and pavement markings communicate critical information to help drivers get safely where they\u2019re going. But if the signs and markings aren\u2019t visible, they might as well not be there at all. And at night, \u201cinvisible\u201d signs can be particularly dangerous.\r\n\r\nRetroreflectivity refers to the ability of a traffic sign to reflect light back to a driver. The Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) has established minimum sign retroreflectivity, and these standards are being phased in over time. FHWA has also started rule making to add minimum pavement marking retroreflectivity requirements to a future edition of its Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. As a result, the Texas Transportation Institute\u2019s (TTI\u2019s) Visibility Research Laboratory \u2014 the only one of its kind in the nation \u2014 is quickly becoming the go-to facility for testing how well signs and pavement markings maintain their \u201csight value\u201d as agencies strive to meet the new standard.", "icon": "https://fbstatic-a.akamaihd.net/rsrc.php/v2/yD/r/aS8ecmYRys0.gif", "type": "link", "id": "311158400744_344093972287685", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "TTI's mission is to solve transportation problems through research, to transfer technology, and to develop diverse human resources to meet the transportation challenges of tomorrow. \u00bb Learn more"}

Doluisio"}]}, "created_time": "2011-12-13T20:47:39+0000", "message": "\"By now, just about every Texan knows the I-35 corridor in Central Texas is the busiest in the state. It's also in the greatest need of expansion. In the coming years, TxDOT has plans to do more than $1 billion of work expanding I-35, particularly in the 100-mile stretch between the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex & Salado. But the projects aren't only about improving I-35, they're about improving communication as well. For more on that improvement, we spoke with Jim Dale, the I-35 Mobility Coordinator, in this week's podcast.\" via Texas Department of Transportation\r\n", "caption": "www.txdot.gov", "type": "link", "id": "311158400744_308615829172219", "status_type": "shared_story", "description": "Listen to TxDOT's statewide podcasts to stay updated on the latest transportation news and issues."}
